source.name: General US recycling best practices
source.notes: Conservative baseline guidance. Check your local municipality for specific rules.

materials.name: Plastic bottles
instructions: Empty and rinse the bottle
Replace the cap
Place in recycling bin
notes: Most curbside programs accept #1 (PET) and #2 (HDPE) plastics
commonMistakes: Don't crush bottles if your program uses optical sorting
Don't include bottles with liquid still in them

materials.name: Plastic containers
instructions: Empty and rinse
Remove any film lids
Place in recycling bin
notes: Check the number on the bottom — #1, #2, and #5 are most commonly accepted
commonMistakes: Black plastic is often not recyclable
Film lids are usually trash

materials.name: Plastic bags
instructions: Do NOT place in curbside recycling
Many grocery stores have drop-off bins for plastic bag recycling
If no drop-off is available, place in trash
notes: Plastic bags jam recycling machinery and are the #1 contaminant
commonMistakes: Never bag your recyclables in plastic bags
Don't put plastic wrap or film in curbside recycling

materials.name: Aluminum cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
No need to crush (unless your program requires it)
Place in recycling bin
notes: Aluminum is infinitely recyclable and one of the most valuable recyclables
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food residue
Aluminum foil is often accepted too — check locally

materials.name: Steel / tin cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
Labels can stay on
Place in recycling bin
notes: Use a magnet to test — steel cans are magnetic, aluminum is not
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food still in them

materials.name: Glass bottles and jars
instructions: Empty and rinse
Remove metal lids (recycle separately)
Place in recycling bin
notes: Some programs separate glass by color; check locally
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass — wrap and trash it
Window glass, mirrors, and ceramics are NOT recyclable in curbside bins

materials.name: Cardboard
instructions: Break down and flatten boxes
Remove tape and packing materials if possible
Place in recycling bin
notes: Cardboard is one of the most successfully recycled materials
commonMistakes: Don't recycle cardboard soaked with grease (e.g., pizza boxes with oil stains)
Remove styrofoam and plastic inserts

materials.name: Newspaper
instructions: Place directly in recycling bin
No need to remove staples
notes: One of the oldest and most commonly recycled materials
commonMistakes: Don't include newspaper that's been used as packing material with food grease

materials.name: Paper
instructions: Place in recycling bin
Shredded paper should be placed in a paper bag first
notes: Most clean, dry paper is recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't include paper towels or tissues (those are compost/trash)
Don't include wax-coated paper

materials.name: Pizza box
instructions: Remove any leftover food
If the box is heavily greased on the bottom, tear off the greasy part and trash it
Recycle the clean top portion
notes: Many modern recycling programs now accept lightly soiled pizza boxes
commonMistakes: Don't include the wax paper liner
A few grease spots are usually OK — a soaking box is not

materials.name: Styrofoam
instructions: Place in trash
Some areas have specialized Styrofoam drop-off locations
notes: Expanded polystyrene (EPS) is not accepted in most curbside programs
commonMistakes: Don't put Styrofoam in recycling — it contaminates the stream
Packing peanuts can sometimes be returned to shipping stores

materials.name: Food waste
instructions: If your area has curbside composting, place in compost bin
Otherwise, consider home composting
If neither is available, place in trash
notes: Food waste in landfills generates methane, a potent greenhouse gas
commonMistakes: Don't put food waste in recycling
Meat and dairy may not be accepted in all composting programs

materials.name: Yard waste
instructions: Place in yard waste bin if available
Many municipalities offer seasonal yard waste pickup
Can also be home composted
notes: Check local rules — some areas ban yard waste from trash
commonMistakes: Don't bag yard waste in plastic bags unless specified
Don't include treated wood or invasive plants

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Never place in regular trash or recycling
Take to a battery recycling drop-off (many hardware stores accept them)
Tape the terminals of lithium batteries before disposal
notes: Batteries can cause fires in garbage trucks and recycling facilities
commonMistakes: Don't throw batteries in the trash
Don't put them in curbside recycling

materials.name: Electronics / E-waste
instructions: Take to an e-waste recycling center
Many retailers (Best Buy, Staples) offer free e-waste drop-off
Delete personal data before disposal
notes: It's illegal to put e-waste in the trash in many states
commonMistakes: Don't put electronics in curbside recycling
Don't throw in trash — contains toxic materials

materials.name: Light bulbs
instructions: CFL and fluorescent bulbs contain mercury — take to a hazardous waste drop-off
LED bulbs can go to e-waste recycling
Incandescent bulbs go in the trash (wrap to prevent breakage)
notes: Home Depot and Lowe's accept CFL bulbs for recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put CFL or fluorescent bulbs in regular trash
Don't break them — mercury vapor is hazardous

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Latex paint: dry it out with kitty litter or sawdust, then trash the solidified paint
Oil-based paint: take to a hazardous waste facility
Never pour paint down the drain
notes: Many communities have paint recycling programs or swap events
commonMistakes: Don't pour paint down the drain or into storm drains
Empty dry paint cans can often be recycled as metal

materials.name: Motor oil
instructions: Collect in a sealed container
Take to an auto parts store or hazardous waste facility
Never pour down drains or on the ground
notes: Most auto parts stores accept used motor oil for free
commonMistakes: Don't mix motor oil with other fluids
Don't pour into storm drains

materials.name: Medications
instructions: Take to a pharmacy drug take-back program
Many police stations have drop-off boxes
If no drop-off available: mix with coffee grounds or kitty litter, seal in a container, and trash
notes: DEA National Prescription Drug Take Back Day happens twice a year
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications down the toilet (unless specifically instructed)
Don't throw in regular trash without rendering unusable

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Donate wearable clothing to thrift stores
Place unwearable textiles in textile recycling bins
Some retailers accept old clothing (H&M, North Face)
notes: Textiles in landfills take decades to decompose
commonMistakes: Don't put clothing in curbside recycling
Wet or moldy clothing should be trashed

materials.name: Aluminum foil
instructions: Clean off food residue
Ball up into a fist-sized ball for easier processing
Place in recycling bin
notes: Many programs accept clean aluminum foil
commonMistakes: Don't recycle foil contaminated with food
Foil-lined chip bags are NOT recyclable

materials.name: Paper towels and napkins
instructions: If you have composting: add to compost bin
Otherwise: place in trash
Never place in recycling
notes: Paper towels cannot be recycled because the fibers are too short
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling
Paper towels used with chemicals should go in trash, not compost

materials.name: Milk / juice cartons
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace cap if it has one
Place in recycling bin
notes: Most curbside programs now accept cartons — check locally
commonMistakes: Don't flatten cartons — 3D shape helps sorting machines identify them

materials.name: Aerosol cans
instructions: Must be completely empty
Do NOT puncture
Remove plastic cap and recycle separately
Place empty can in recycling bin
notes: Non-empty aerosols may be considered hazardous waste
commonMistakes: Don't recycle if still pressurized or has product remaining
Never puncture aerosol cans

materials.name: Cooking oil / grease
instructions: Let cool completely
Pour into a sealed non-recyclable container
Place sealed container in trash
Some areas have cooking oil recycling programs
notes: Never pour oil or grease down the drain — it causes sewer blockages
commonMistakes: Don't pour down the sink
Don't pour into storm drains

materials.name: Diapers
instructions: Wrap used diapers tightly
Place in trash
notes: Diapers are not recyclable or compostable in most municipal programs
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling
Some specialty services offer diaper composting — check locally

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups
instructions: Most paper coffee cups are NOT recyclable due to plastic lining
Place in trash
Plastic lids are often recyclable — check locally
notes: Consider using a reusable cup to reduce waste
commonMistakes: Don't put lined paper cups in recycling
The plastic lid and paper sleeve may be recyclable separately

materials.name: Wine corks
instructions: Natural cork: compost or recycle at specialty programs
Synthetic cork: place in trash
Whole Foods and some wine shops accept corks for recycling
notes: Natural cork is biodegradable
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside recycling

materials.name: Tires
instructions: Take to a tire retailer or auto shop
Many municipalities offer tire collection events
Never dump illegally
notes: Most tire retailers are required to accept old tires when you buy new ones
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside trash
Don't dump in nature

materials.name: Needles / sharps
instructions: Place in an FDA-cleared sharps container
When full, take to a designated drop-off or mail-back program
Never place loose sharps in trash or recycling
notes: Improper disposal puts sanitation workers at risk
commonMistakes: Never put in recycling
Never put loose in trash bags
Don't flush down the toilet

materials.name: Propane tanks
instructions: Never place in trash or recycling
Small camping canisters: check for local hazardous waste collection
Large tanks: return to a propane dealer for refill or exchange
notes: Pressurized containers are a fire and explosion risk in garbage trucks
commonMistakes: Never puncture
Don't put in curbside bins

materials.name: Mattress
instructions: Schedule a bulk pickup with your municipality
Take to a mattress recycling facility
Some retailers offer take-back when delivering a new mattress
notes: Mattresses are recyclable — steel springs, foam, and fabric can all be recovered
commonMistakes: Don't leave on the curb without scheduling pickup
Don't put in dumpsters without permission

materials.name: Bubble wrap / packing materials
instructions: Bubble wrap and air pillows: deflate and trash (or drop off with plastic bags at grocery stores)
Packing peanuts: return to shipping stores like UPS
Don't place in curbside recycling
notes: Plastic film clogs recycling machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside recycling
Don't let packing peanuts blow into the environment

materials.name: Fluorescent tubes
instructions: Contains mercury — handle with care
Take to a hazardous waste facility or participating retailer
Home Depot and Lowe's accept fluorescent tubes
notes: If a tube breaks, ventilate the area and clean up carefully
commonMistakes: Don't put in regular trash
Don't break them

materials.name: Wax paper / parchment paper
instructions: Place in trash
Not recyclable due to wax or silicone coating
notes: Uncoated parchment paper may be compostable — check locally
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling
Don't confuse with regular paper

compost: Food scraps (fruit, vegetables, coffee grounds, eggshells)
Paper towels and napkins (unbleached, no chemicals)
Meat and dairy (in most municipal programs)

tips: When in doubt, throw it out — contamination hurts recycling
Rinse containers but they don't need to be spotless
Check your local municipality's specific rules
Never bag recyclables in plastic bags
Keep recyclables loose in the bin
